etymologies: Middle English (in the sense ‘move quickly and softly’): probably from Middle Low German slippen (verb); compare with slippery

definitions: (of a person or animal) slide unintentionally for a short distance, typically losing one's balance or footing

examples.text: I slipped on the ice
he kept slipping in the mud

shortDefinitions: lose one's footing and slide unintentionally for short distance

definitions: (of a thing) accidentally slide or move out of position or from someone's grasp

examples.text: the envelope slipped through Luke's fingers
a wisp of hair had slipped down over her face

shortDefinitions: accidentally slide or move out of position or from someone's grasp

definitions: fail to grip or make proper contact with a surface

examples.text: the front wheels began to slip

shortDefinitions: fail to grip or make proper contact with surface

definitions: go or move quietly or quickly, without attracting notice

examples.text: we slipped out by a back door
I slipped out of bed and into my clothes

shortDefinitions: go or move quietly or quickly

definitions: put (something) in a particular place or position quietly, quickly, or stealthily

examples.text: she slipped the map into her pocket
Carrie slipped her arm through his
she slipped off her black heels
I slipped him a ten-spot to keep quiet

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: put something in place quietly or stealthily

definitions: put on (a garment) quickly and easily

examples.text: Sarah slipped into a red jacket

shortDefinitions: put on garment

definitions: take off (a garment) quickly and easily

examples.text: in the bathroom she quickly slipped out of her clothes

shortDefinitions: take off garment

definitions: pass or change to a lower, worse, or different condition, typically in a gradual or imperceptible way

examples.text: many people feel standards have slipped
profits slipped 31 percent

shortDefinitions: pass or change to lower, worse, or different condition

definitions: be behaving in a way that is not up to one's usual level of performance

examples.text: you're slipping, Joe—you need a vacation

shortDefinitions: be behaving in way that is not up to one's usual level of performance

definitions: escape or get loose from (a means of restraint)

examples.text: the giant balloon slipped its moorings

shortDefinitions: escape or get loose from

definitions: (of a thought or fact) fail to be remembered by (one's mind or memory); elude (one's notice)

examples.text: a beautiful woman's address was never likely to slip his mind

shortDefinitions: fail to be remembered by

definitions: release (an animal, typically a hunting dog) from restraint

examples.text: they slipped the hounds, the hare racing for the side of the hill

shortDefinitions: release animal from restraint

definitions: move (a stitch) to the other needle without knitting it

examples.text: slip the next twelve stitches onto a stitch holder

shortDefinitions: move stitch to other needle without knitting it

definitions: release (the clutch of a motor vehicle) slightly or for a moment

examples.text: I gunned the engine, slipping the clutch slightly

shortDefinitions: release clutch of motor vehicle slightly or for moment

definitions: (of an animal) produce (dead young) prematurely; abort

examples.text: if you twist a mare's back too sharply it can slip foal

shortDefinitions: (of animal) produce dead young prematurely

phrases.text: there's many a slip 'twixt cup and lip

definitions: an act of sliding unintentionally for a short distance

examples.text: a single slip could send them plummeting down the mountainside

shortDefinitions: act of sliding unintentionally for short distance

definitions: relative movement of an object or surface and a solid surface in contact with it.
shortDefinitions: relative movement of object or surface

definitions: a reduction in the movement of a pulley or other mechanism due to slipping of the belt, rope, etc.
shortDefinitions: reduction in movement of pulley due to slipping of belt

definitions: a sideways movement of an aircraft in flight, typically downward toward the center of curvature of a turn

examples.text: the slip is used to get rid of excess height
the effects of slight slip on turns

shortDefinitions: sideways movement of aircraft in flight

definitions: the extent of relative horizontal displacement of corresponding points on either side of a fault plane

examples.text: a slip plane

shortDefinitions: extent of horizontal displacement of points on side of fault plane

definitions: a fall to a lower level or standard

examples.text: a continued slip in house prices

shortDefinitions: fall to lower level or standard

definitions: a minor or careless mistake

examples.text: the judge made a slip in his summing up

shortDefinitions: minor or careless mistake

definitions: a woman's loose-fitting, dress- or skirt-length undergarment, suspended by shoulder straps (full slip) or by an elasticized waistband (half slip)

examples.text: a silk slip

shortDefinitions: loose-fitting garment

definitions: a slope built leading into water, used for launching and landing boats and ships or for building and repairing them

examples.text: he brought his steamer to the yard for overhaul at his old employer's slip

definitions: a space in which to dock a boat or ship, especially between two wharves or piers.
shortDefinitions: space in which to dock boat or ship

definitions: a leash which enables a dog to be released quickly

examples.text: Tommy bolted off like a greyhound released from the slips

shortDefinitions: leash which enables dog to be released quickly

examples.text: one color at a time should be knitted in striped slip

phrases.text: there's many a slip 'twixt cup and lip

etymologies: late Middle English: probably from Middle Dutch, Middle Low German slippe ‘cut, strip’

definitions: a small piece of paper, typically a form for writing on or one giving printed information

examples.text: his monthly salary slip
complete the tear-off slip below

shortDefinitions: small piece of paper

definitions: a long, narrow strip of a thin material such as wood.
shortDefinitions: long, narrow strip of thin material such as wood

definitions: a cutting taken from a plant for grafting or planting; a scion.
shortDefinitions: cutting taken from plant for grafting or planting

etymologies: mid 17th century: of obscure origin; compare with Norwegian slip(a) ‘slime’

definitions: a creamy mixture of clay, water, and typically a pigment, used especially for decorating earthenware.
shortDefinitions: creamy mixture of clay, water, and pigment
